description:
A Tradition of Innovation
Berkeley Engineering is a community that is dedicated to creating tomorrow's leaders and supporting today's pioneers. Students and researchers from around the world are drawn to Berkeley by its outstanding reputation, its internationally recognized faculty and its strong tradition of impact in research and teaching.

Earlier Berkeley engineers brought water to California's great agricultural lands, pioneered the microelectronics that seeded Silicon Valley and helped build the unbuildable in structures like Hoover Dam and the Golden Gate Bridge. Today, Berkeley engineers in every field remain at the center of technological innovation worldwide.

Our Mission
To educate men and women for careers of leadership and innovation in engineering and related fields
To expand the base of engineering knowledge through original research and by developing technology to serve the needs of society
To benefit the public through service to industry, government and the engineering profession

Our Vision
Increasingly rapid advances in technology are creating unprecedented opportunities for innovation in every field of engineering. Today, opportunities to benefit society through engineering advancements are unparalleled in history. As a national leader in engineering education, Berkeley's College of Engineering is positioned to make major contributions in this era of opportunity.

Berkeley Engineering continues to rank No. 3 in the top undergraduate engineering schools nationwide, according to U.S. News & World Report’s 2025 rankings. The college also remains the top public engineering program.

Scenes from the Berkeley Space Symposium 2024, hosted by NewSpace@Berkeley, at the Pauley Ballroom on Oct. 11. (Photos by Adam Lau / Berkeley Engineering)

“I’ve had a profound interest in aerospace for as long as I can remember.

Entering my freshman year of high school in Portland, Oregon, I endured multiple surgeries that left me unable to walk independently for nearly three years. What could have been a time of isolation for me instead became a catalyst for some of the most meaningful and fulfilling projects I’ve ever initiated. This experience ultimately fueled my curiosity and motivation to become an engineer and led me to intern at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Vast, a startup building the next-generation space station.

Between physical therapy and school, I dug into aerospace life support systems research through the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (2x International Grand Awardee), solo-publishing in the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) SciTech conference journal my senior year. I also was the first woman to lead my school’s aerospace team, where we became the The American Rocketry Challenge National Champions in 2021.

Throughout my experience as an engineer in a predominantly male-dominated industry, I have consistently found myself being one of the only women in the room, if not the only one. I strive to challenge this status quo by creating spaces where women are celebrated, supported and given opportunities to lead.

I co-lead outreach for the Association of Women in Aerospace here at Berkeley and previously co-founded the AIAA student branch, both of which are focused on providing industry-to-student, aerospace-related opportunities for the UC Berkeley undergraduate student population. This builds on work I did previously with the Portland State Aerospace Society, as I led a four-part aerospace career panel with industry professionals for 400+ high school students during COVID-19 lockdown.

I’m excited to continue paving the way for young women who are passionate about aerospace, while deepening my own skills and expertise as a mechanical engineer.”

— Kara Gaiser (B.S.’26 ME) #VoicesOfBE
